title: Authors and Citation
text: Wheeler S, Clack D (2023). final.best.lm: Best Linear Model. R package version 0.0.0.9000.
code: @Manual{,   title = {final.best.lm: Best Linear Model},   author = {Sam Wheeler and Dylan Clack},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000}, }

title: Best Linear Model
text: ever dependent variable wanted predict certain number predictor variables? wanted find best model predict certain variable? Maybe house price, gas mileage, air pollution? package final.best.lm contains function best.lm create best possible linear model specified number predictor variables. splits data training test set, sizes sets can changed â€œtrain_sizeâ€ parameter. iterates every possible linear model finds best one based adjusted R squared mean squared error.

title: Best Linear Model

title: Best Linear Model
text: basic example shows solve common problem:

title: best.linmod â€” best.linmod
text: best.lm function create best possible linear model specified number predictor variables. splits data training test set, sizes sets can changed "train_size" parameter. iterates every possible linear model finds best one based adjusted R squared mean squared error.

title: best.linmod â€” best.linmod
code: best.linmod(   data,   response_var,   num_predictors = length(data) - 1,   train_size = 0.8 )

title: best.linmod â€” best.linmod
text: data dataset response_var dependent variable num_predictors number predictor variables, default number variables -1 train_size percentage data want allocate training set, default 0.8

title: best.linmod â€” best.linmod
text: summary including dependent variable, predictor variables, percentage variation dependent variable predictor variables account .

title: best.linmod â€” best.linmod
code: best.linmod(mtcars, "mpg") #> Dependent variable: mpg #> Best 10 predictor variables: cyl + disp + hp + drat + wt + qsec + vs + am + gear + carb #> These predictor variables account for 83.7 % of the variation in your dependent variable. best.linmod(mtcars, "mpg", 4, 0.7) #> Dependent variable: mpg #> Best 4 predictor variables: cyl + disp + hp + wt #> These predictor variables account for 86.8 % of the variation in your dependent variable.
